3.2 Structural Requirements
Elevation Standards: Structures must be elevated to Base Flood Elevation (BFE) plus freeboard

Hattiesburg Requirement: 2 feet above BFE per Hattiesburg Code ยง4-29
Flood Protection Elevation: BFE + 2 feet freeboard = minimum structural elevation
Foundation Requirements: Structures must be designed to be anchored to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement due to the effects of wind and flood loads

Access Requirements: NFIP requires at least one access route above BFE; address roadway elevation or alternate egress in design

3.3 Allowable Construction Methods
Elevated Construction: Buildings on pilings/columns with open areas below BFE Flood-Resistant Materials: Below BFE elevation Breakaway Walls: If designed to ASCE 24 standards Elevated Utilities: Above BFE

4. Market Analysis
4.1 Housing Demand Context
Population Impact: Hattiesburg has 46,377 residents with roughly 25 percent of property located within a special flood hazard area (SFHA)

Reconstruction Precedent: Many properties have been elevated due to reconstruction that came after devastating tornadoes in 2013 and 2017

Flood Risk Areas: Several areas outside of the SFHA also pose a concern, as they are subject to flash flooding during intense rainfall

4.2 Development Opportunity
Housing Market Context: Significant housing demand exists for flood-resilient construction in Hattiesburg's flood-prone areas, with established precedent for elevated construction and municipal support for higher building standards.

Insurance Economics: CRS Class 7 designation provides 15% flood insurance premium reduction, enhancing affordability of compliant elevated construction. Consider private-market flood policies for additional savings on elevated structures.
